subsection.p: Because of federal privacy laws, all email communications related to this class need to be sent to and from your @pcc.edu email address.
I have drop-in office hours where you do not need to make an appointmentjust come by!

Come visit me for help with the material, help with homework, or questions about your grade. If those times are not workable for you, please feel comfortable contacting me to make some other arrangements.
While I do have an office phone number and voice mail, I am more likely to reply to you more quickly if you use email to contact me.

section.title: Course Description
section.p: Taken from the official PCC course description:

Introduces algebraic concepts and processes with a focus on linear systems, polynomials, quadratic equations, and functions. Emphasizes applications, graphs, formulas, and proper mathematical notation throughout the course. A scientific calculator may be required. The TI-30X II is recommended. Prerequisites: (MTH 60 or MTH 62) and (RD 80 or ESOL 250) or equivalent placement. Recommended that MTH 60 or MTH 62 be taken within the past 4 terms. The PCC math department recommends that students take MTH courses in consecutive terms. Audit available.
The complete Course Content and Outcome Guide can be found at www.pcc.edu/ccog/.

section.title: Expectations
section.p:
MTH 65 can be a challenging course, so the main expectation is that you commit to the course with the goal of passing with an A and play an active role in your learning. We will be using the flipped model of teaching math. For each day of class
You will watch roughly one hour of video lectures before coming to class.
You will take notes on the video lecture and turn them in when class starts. We call these the class prep assignments. Download and print the class prep video lecture notes to fill in while you watch the videos.
In class we will work together in groups doing math exercises. We call these the group activity assignments.
You have some online homework to complete within five or six days of the in-class practice.
There is evidence that the flipped model can raise the success rates in math courses. More traditional methods for running a class have recently led to an average 60% pass rate in MTH 65. Flipping might raise this, and those who do pass are more likely to pass with an A.

Additionally, please:
Try to complete all homework assignments earlier than the due date. Begin working on homework assignments the same day that we discuss that material in class.
Make plans to visit me in office hours.

The ideas are covered in a natural sequence, and if you stay on top of the assignments, you have a high chance for success.
All students are further encouraged to work togethercollaboration is an important part of any activity, and it is almost always beneficial for all involved.

Here are some other expectations:
Maintain respect for yourself and your classmates.
Do not use phones, tablets, or computers during class time unless it is directly related to a class activity.
Check your @pcc.edu email at least once a day.
Food and drink can be distracting to other students. Out of respect for others, please do not bring food and drink to class. (Beverages that do not smell strongly and are in spill-proof containers are OK.)

section.title: Technology Requirements
section.p: You will need Internet access for most of your homework. If you do not have Internet access at home, you can find it in PCC computer labs.

Part of this course involves practicing algebra skills, where in the middle of the process you may have to calculate something like \frac{3.1}{1.2}. If you are comfortable doing that by hand, then great. You can rest assured that all exams will give you adequate time to do calculations like this, even if you are doing them with only pencil and paper.

However you are permitted to use a basic or scientific calculator for parts of exams to speed up steps like this. In the lead-up to each exam I will be more specific about how/if calculator use will be permitted. Pretty much any calculator is acceptable if it is not a graphing calculator. Dollar stores sell very cheap calculators that will work fine for this class. If you are unsure about your calculator, bring it to me.

section.title: Textbook
section.p: We are using a new free textbook written by PCC faculty. The book is called ORCCA (Open Resources for Community College Algebra). We are excited to replace a roughly $117 book with this free book and save you money. This is only the second year this book is being used for MTH 65 at PCC, and we will be asking you for your thoughts and feedback about it. We will work to make it better every term from here on out, so that future students have a free, excellent MTH 65 textbook.
If you find any issues with this book where you think we could make it better, please let me know about each one.

Access this book:
as a free eBook at spot.pcc.edu/math/orcca/.
as a (color or black-and-white) PDF for download at spot.pcc.edu/math/orcca/pdf.
for purchase from the PCC book store for $15.40.
for purchase from Amazon (amzn.to/2Oo4Zbz) for $15.40.

introduction.p: General PCC Grading Guidelines are found at catalog.pcc.edu/handbook/g301-gradingguidelines.

paragraphs.title: Class Prep Assignments
paragraphs.p: Most class days you are supposed to come to class with class prep notes completed. Download and print the class prep video lecture notes. You will show these to me at some point during class. Then while you work on some warm-up exercises, I will look over your prep assignments and give you credit for them. Each one is worth 0.5% of your grade. There are 17 of these total, so all together they are worth 8.5% of your grade.
If you miss class, you may bring the completed class prep assignment to me the next class session.

paragraphs.title: In-class Group Work
paragraphs.p: Most class days, you will work in small groups on a collection of exercises that go along with the lesson you prepared for. If you work on these diligently during class time with your partners, you will get credit for 0.5% of your final grade for each one (even if your group is not able to finish these in time). There are 17 of these, so in total these are worth 8.5% of your grade.

If you miss class, you may bring a fully completed activity to me within one week and still get the 0.5% credit. It must be fully completed, not partially completed. The work must be shown, not just the answers.
Blank group activities are available for download at or .

paragraphs.title: Online Homework
paragraphs.p: Most of your homework for this class is to be submitted online through the free program . For details, see . Collectively, all web assignments are worth 11% of your final grade. For every web assignment that you do not submit (or have a poor score for), I will replace that score with the score you get on your next exam.

paragraphs.title: Exams
paragraphs.p: Please refer to or for exam dates, and to for details about what is covered on each exam. Exams 1, 2, and 3 are each worth 24%, of your grade.

paragraphs.title: Introduction
paragraphs.p: I have made an account for you on a program called at webwork.pcc.edu/webwork2/mth065-jordan-201902. Each week I will assign problem sets for you in . The assignments are either due Sunday night or in the middle of the following week, but can be worked on much earlier. You may submit answers any time before the due date. You may work from home or use PCC computer labs to turn in your answers.
Here is an example of what a problem is like.

statement.p: Use the properties of exponents to simplify .

solution.p: We add the exponents as follows: &=x^{+}&=x^{}

statement.p: Use the properties of exponents to simplify {x^{4}x^{3}}\text{.}

solution.p: We add the exponents as follows:

paragraphs.title: Why are we using online homework? And why WeBWorK?
paragraphs.p: Traditionally, homework comes from textbook problems that students would do on paper, and then turn in in to the instructor. One drawback of this is that students get no feedback at all until about a week later, and at that point the student is no longer actively thinking about material from two weeks earlier. Another drawback is that it is impossible for a student to do the appropriate amount of homework and for the instructor to give quality feedback for every single exercise. Often an instructor is only able to give feedback for a small subset of the exercises. Using brings the following advantages over traditional homework.

li.title: Cost
li.p: is free, unlike most online homework programs.

li.title: Timely Feedback
li.p: Rather than waiting a week for written feedback from your instructor, you get instant feedback from .

li.title: Quality Feedback
li.p: will do more than just tell you if you are right or wrong. For example, it will usually tell you if you haven't completely simplified an answer or forgot to include units when they are required. Sometimes it will do even more. Try entering x^12 as the answer to .

li.title: Ease of Communication
li.p: encourages you to write your instructor for help, who can provide even higher quality feedback based on your message and your previous attempts.

li.title: Multiple or Unlimited Attempts
li.p: On paper, when you submit an answer, that's the end of it. With you might get a problem wrong on your first attempt, but you are encouraged to figure out your mistakes and try again.

li.title: Efficient Use of Class Time
li.p: Your instructor can monitor the whole class and see in real-time which problems and concepts are causing the class difficulty.

li.title: Extra Practice
li.p: Your instructor can set things up so that you can retry each problem with new random numbers involved. If you are unsure if you have mastered a skill, this gives you a way to keep practicing.

paragraphs.title: Logging in to WeBWorK
paragraphs.p: Click any of the logos on this page, or go directly to webwork.pcc.edu/webwork2/mth065-jordan-201902. If you are working at your own computer, you might want to bookmark this link. Your username is your PCC email prefix, using all lowercase letters. For example, mine is alex.jordan because my email address is alex.jordan@pcc.edu. Your initial password is your PCC G-number, using a capital G.

paragraphs.title: The First Time You Log On
paragraphs.p: You should go to the User Settings menu in the upper left and change your password. There is an Orientation assignment for you to take. Click on the Orientation, and begin by reading the paragraph to the right that says Read This First. Take the time to complete the Orientation, and you will understand a lot about how behaves. The Orientation will remain available to you for the entire term, so you can always come back and look at it again.

paragraphs.title: Homework Sets Menu
paragraphs.p:
This shows you the assignments that have been assigned to you and when they are due. You may:
click on an assignment and begin working on problems online
check the box next to an assignment and click Download Hardcopy to get the assignment as a .pdf file which you may then print to work on away from a computer.

When you click on an assignment, you will see a screen with the problem numbers listed. Off to the right is a message for you that might have specific instructions or information about the assignment. You should always look for and read this message.

paragraphs.title: Emailing for Help
paragraphs.p: When you are stumped, you can click the Email Instructor button at the bottom of any problem. Write a message explaining what you have tried and if possible, include the work from your calculations. will send your instructor an email with helpful information (like all of the incorrect attempts you have tried) and they get back to you soon with a response. When they respond, it will be with an email, so you must remember to check your email.

paragraphs.title: Math Achievements
paragraphs.p: As you complete more problems through the term, you will win badges for various achievements. For example, the On One Hand badge is for completing a homework set with fewer than five incorrect submissions. Both earning badges and just plain answering questions correctly will earn you achievement points. As you gain more achievement points, you will level up. Each time you level up, you earn an item that can be used to affect your grade.

li.title: Level 1: Lesser Rod of Revelation
li.p: Give yourself 50% credit on one problem.

li.title: Level 2: Potion of Forgetfulness
li.p: Drop the number incorrect attempts down to 0.

li.title: Level 3: Tunic of Extension
li.p: Extend the due date of a currently open homework for 24 hours.

li.title: Level 4: Cupcake of Enlargement
li.p: Double the weight of one problem.

li.title: Level 5: Box of Transmogrification
li.p: Change a single problem to be a (newly randomized) copy of a different problem on the same homework set.

li.title: Level 6: Greater Rod of Revelation
li.p: Give yourself 100% credit on one problem.

li.title: Level 7: Robe of Longevity
li.p: Extend the due date of a currently open homework for 48 hours.

li.title: Level 8: Scroll of Resurrection
li.p: Reopen a homework set (even a closed one) for an additional 24 hours. All problems will be re-randomized.

li.title: Level 9: Greater Tome of Enlightenment
li.p: Earn 100% on every problem in a single homework set.

li.title: Level 10: Cake of Enlargement
li.p: Double the weight of an entire set.

introduction.p: Please see or for the exam dates.
About a week before each exam, you will receive a practice exam. Practice exams are typically longer than the real exam to give you more to practice with.

li.title: Exam 1
li.p: Covers sections 5.16.6.
You'll have the entire class period for this exam if you need it.

li.title: Exam 2
li.p: Covers sections 7.18.1. Additionally there will be some repeated questions from Exam 1. (So part of your studying should be reviewing your first exam.)
You'll have the entire class period for this exam if you need it.

li.title: Exam 3
li.p: Covers sections 8.29.3. Additionally there will be some repeated questions from Exams 1 and 2. (So part of your studying should be reviewing your first and second exams.)
This exam is during finals week and is only two hours long.

paragraphs.title: Missing an Exam
paragraphs.p: If you miss an exam, you must contact me within one day to explain why or I might not be able to allow a make-up and you would receive a zero. Make-up exams are only permitted under extreme circumstances. PCC does not have enough staff and facilities to administer too many make-up exams. If you have a valid excuse, you must make up the exam within the next two business days, or I might not be able to allow a make-up and you would receive a zero. If you are going to make up the exam, contact the testing center immediately (www.pcc.edu/resources/testing/proctored) to learn what time you might be able to make up the exam. If you are going to miss the final exam, contact me before the test is given. Since make-up testing is occasionally abused, if you require a make-up test for more than two exams, your scores on all make-up exams will be reduced by 10 percentage points.
Above all else, get in contact with me if you have missed or will miss an exam. Space and time to make up an exam is limited. You need to make arrangements as soon as there is an issue.

paragraphs.title: Accommodated Testing
paragraphs.p: Students who experience disability-related barriers should contact Disability Services: www.pcc.edu/disability. If students elect to use approved academic adjustments, they must provide, in advance, formal notification from Disability Services to the instructor. Exam accommodations may include, but are not limited to, extended time and a distraction-free environment.

introduction.p: PCC and the world at large offer several resources that you may benefit from while taking this course.

paragraphs.title: Tutoring
paragraphs.p: The Tutoring Center at Sylvania offers free tutoring in math. You should find some time to check it out, if you haven't already. Details can be found at www.pcc.edu/resources/tutoring/sylvania.
Visit www.pcc.edu/resources/tutoring/sylvania/student-success/math-center for details about free online tutoring that you have access to as well.

paragraphs.title: PCC Student Learning Center Math Self-Study Resources
paragraphs.p: Some PCC faculty have been putting together self-study material for mathematics topics, including the topics in this course. If you would like to see an alternative to what is in your textbook, please visit spot.pcc.edu/slc/mathresources/output/html/.

paragraphs.title: College Success Courses
paragraphs.p: There are several one-credit courses available to help you maximize your success in the college experience. These include courses specifically geared toward study skills. The following site offers information on these courses as well as tips for success: www.pcc.edu/resources/panther-tracks/college-success/study-skills.html.

paragraphs.title: Math Study Skills
paragraphs.p: PCC instructor Jessica Bernards co-authored these free lessons on study skills that help people succeed in math courses. spot.pcc.edu/mathstudyskills

paragraphs.title: Online Videos
paragraphs.p: At the Khan Academy (www.khanacademy.org) you can find thousands of 10- to 30-minute videos on various mathematics topics. See what you can find that may be relevant to the topics we are studying in class using appropriate search terms.
Khan Academy is just one such site. See what else you can find online searching for math videos. If you find a series of videos that you feel is helpful, keep visiting them as the term progresses.

paragraphs.title: Counseling Services
paragraphs.p: Get help dealing with personal or career concerns that may be impacting your academic success. Trained professional counselors can also assist you with decision-making, goal-setting, and personal development.
www.pcc.edu/resources/counseling.

paragraphs.title: Multicultural Center
paragraphs.p: A welcoming and inclusive space for diverse students. One of the many services is one-on-one help for math courses, drop-in or by appointment:

paragraphs.title: Queer Resource Center
paragraphs.p: A welcoming and safe space to hang out and be yourself. Free computer use, coffee and more:

paragraphs.title: Student Computing Center
paragraphs.p: Internet access, mathematics computer programs, and more (orientation required).
Allocation of 100 double-sided pages of free printing per term (does not roll over to next term).

paragraphs.title: Student Learning Center
paragraphs.p: An informal, open study area, with the added benefit of free tutoring assistance. The Math Center resides here. For more information:

paragraphs.title: Veteran's Resource Center
paragraphs.p: Relax, connect, computer workstations, work study and volunteer opportunities, and more. For additional information:

paragraphs.title: Women's Resource Center
paragraphs.p: A wide variety of services that support the academic achievement of women:

paragraphs.title: ADA Accommodation
paragraphs.p: Students who experience disability-related barriers should contact Disability Services: www.pcc.edu/disability. If students elect to use approved academic adjustments, they must provide, in advance, formal notification from Disability Services to the instructor.

paragraphs.title: Email Notice
paragraphs.p: Due to Federal laws and concerns about privacy, all email communication between instructor and student shall be done via PCC assigned email address. Access email via MyPCCsee instructor during office hours if unfamiliar with using MyPCC.

paragraphs.title: Equity & Inclusion Nondiscrimination Nonharassment (Title IX)
paragraphs.p: Portland Community College is committed to creating and fostering a learning and working environment based on open communication and mutual respect. This is an integral part of the College's academic mission to enrich our students' educational experiences and prepare them to live in and contribute to a global society. If you believe you have encountered sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, sexual assault, or discrimination based on race, color, religion, age, national origin, veteran status, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or disability please contact the Office of Equity and Inclusion at (971) 722-5840 or equity.inclusion@pcc.edu.

paragraphs.title: Flexibility Statement
paragraphs.p: The instructor reserves the right to modify course content and/or substitute assignments and learning activities in response to institutional, weather, or class situations. Flash Alert Messenger is a free service that delivers closure information: www.pcc.edu/about/announcements/closure-information.html

paragraphs.title: Sanctuary College
paragraphs.p: PCC is a sanctuary college. For more information and resources, see: www.pcc.edu/resources/undocumented-students

paragraphs.title: Grading and Registration Policies and Deadlines
Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook
paragraphs.p: Students are required to comply with the Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook. Included are policies on Students Rights, Student Conduct, Grade Appeal, Academic Integrity, Consensual Relationship Statement, and Children on PCC properties.
